job_title: Doctor in Luton, East of England, England
pros:
Emergency Department in particular was led by a group of motivated consultants who show care for their juniors' wellbeing by means of encouraging study leave and being quite flexible with annual leave. Normally lots of support on shift from senior colleagues, sometimes less so overnight with some staff specialists. I am sure the positive environment impacts well on patient care. I hope this continues with the change in leadership in the ED.  
As a junior doctor it is uncommon to come in contact with the CEO but she stood out among other CEOs by sending us thank you letters following particularly busy periods.
cons:
Certain consultants said they were afraid of speaking up about problems for fear of repercussions. Interesting that I didn't feel this way as a junior but perhaps it suggests poor leadership between consultants. 
Workload on the medical take and ward cover is often unmanageable, though not as bad as some other hospitals.
Terrible cafeteria with a menu that is unhealthy and probably hasn't been updated since 1990. And it's cash only! No free ATM in the hospital. 
The area is not particularly enjoyable; there is nothing to do nearby. Also because everyone drives home, this does limit after-work socialising compared to a city centre hospital. 
Staff have to pay for parking.

job_title: Healthcare Assistant in Luton, East of England, England
pros: The people, the staff, the patients... I'm a people's person, that is why inspite of being a design professional, I have worked in Healthcare, as a Stroke Care Assistant for the past 9 years and not felt out of place.
cons: Doctors often are too busy and this affects patient care. The fabulous nurses, though, keep riding their backs and remind them of each and every patient who needs their ( the docs') attention! sometimes, especially in A & E, waiting times are unbelievably long and exhausting.... but that's everywhere, they say. In my own experience, the A & E staff  are really busy and have always done their best for us. but as a patient and a parent of a child waiting to be seen, I felt the doctor ( one of them only, on 3 occasions) has been condescending, unmindful of peoples' privacy and confidentiality and their emotional vulnerability...

job_title: Administrative in Luton, East of England, England
pros:
- Public sector employer so they are more likely to treat you well
- You will be well trained for all parts of your job
- You are likely to meet lots of different people on your day to day duties as there is a lot of (good) communication between the departments
cons:
- Due to budget cuts jobs are not as secure as they used to be.
- Some employees in the administrative areas have been working there for years with no progression, this has led to low morale. 
- Poor lighting (some people like the sun light).

job_title: Head of Communications in Hitchin, England
pros: This is a top performing hospital providing excellent clinical care to people in and around Luton. It is the staff and leadership that make it a great hospital. So proud to have worked there.
cons: The need to meet performance-targets can sometimes be overbearing and can affect staff morale. Which is why staff engagement is critical to the success of a dynamic and large organisation.

cons: The building is being developed so there is a lot of construction work going on in and around the hospital.
